title: also makes this argument in his essay “Thematics.” For a more recent look at repetition as building theme within narrative fiction
For an in-​depth discussion of the importance of sequence, succession for the intelligibility of plot, see Caserio
Usually, this speaker is identified as Dos Passos himself, since these sections are heavily autobiographical and correlate with events and impressions from Dos Passos’s life

Mac joins up with the I.W.W. and the Anarchist Union of Industry and Agriculture in his narrative sections. Big Bill Haywood, founding member and leader of the I.W.W. and member of the Western Federation of Miners, appears both as a character in Mac’s narrative and in a separate historical biography

container-title: she writes, “narrative and sexuality operate within the reproductive and/or productive, metaphorically Notes to Pages
title: For an extensive treatment of traditional narrative and its link to heteronormativity, see Judith Roof: “Interwound with one another
Michael Reynolds also experiments with breaking Hemingway’s prose into verse lines in his study Hemingway’s First War

container-title: briefly touches on Hemingway’s stylistic influence on DeLillo. See also Cowart’s discussion of Hemingway’s imprint on End Zone and Mao II

title: For a reading of the juxtaposition of these two plots and what they might reveal about the relationship between plot and motive, see Bérubé
DeLillo maintains that this juxtaposition on the front page of the October 4, 1951, edition of the New York Times inspired Underworld. See his essay “The Power of History
For an analysis of the expectations readers typically bring to narrative fiction and the ways in which these expectations shape the act of interpretation, see Rabinowitz
